answers.explanation: One of the key amendments in the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, is redefining the threshold of ‘substantial interest’ from ₹5 lakh to ₹2 crore, revising a limit that had remained unchanged since 1968.
Primary markets remained robust during FY24, facilitating capital formation of ₹10.9 lakh crore, compared to ₹9.3 lakh crore in FY23. (page 110)
The Government of the Republic of India and the Government of the State of Israel signed a Bilateral Investment Agreement (BIA) in New Delhi on 8th September 2025.
As per the first advance estimates released by the National Statistical Office (MoSPI), the real gross domestic product (GDP) growth for FY25 is estimated to be 6.4 per cent. (Page 56, Para 1.22)
The weighted average call rate (WACR), on an average, traded 6 bps above the policy repo rate during 2024-25. (Page 31, 80)

Clause 18 amends the Explanation in Section 80-IAC, extending the date of incorporation for eligible start-ups from '2025' to '2030', meaning the benefit is available to start-ups incorporated before 1st April, 2030. (Page 43, Page 148)
The gross non-performing assets (GNPA) ratio of scheduled commercial banks fell to a multi-year low of 2.6 per cent in September 2024, buoyed by falling slippages and higher write-offs. (Page 55)

In a significant policy shift, India signed the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) in August 2025. This decision came after certain modifications were incorporated into the trade deal, addressing India's earlier concerns.

The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI) implemented a major reform in February 2025 by increasing the FDI limit in the insurance sector to 74% from the previous cap of 49%.
The Union Budget 2025-26, presented by the Finance Minister, set the fiscal deficit target for the financial year 2025-26 at 4.9% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to reduce the policy repo rate under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) by 50 basis points to 5.50 per cent with immediate effect. (Page 7)

The revised Directions included the inclusion of non-statutory liquidity ratio (SLR) securities in the HTM category, subject to fulfilling certain conditions. It did not mandate the inclusion of all SLR securities. Other mentioned modifications are correct as per the report. (Page 145, para VI.27)
In its February 2025 meeting, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously decided to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points, bringing it down from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent. (Page 8)

Chapter IV of the Finance (No. 2) Bill, 2024, is titled 'THE DIRECT TAX VIVAD SE VISHWAS SCHEME, 2024'. Section 88(1) states, 'This Scheme may be called the Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024.' (Page 80)
The CRAR of NBFCs stood at 27.6 per cent in September 2023, which is well above the regulatory minimum of 15 per cent, indicating substantial capital buffers. (Page 19, 71)
In May 2025, India's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) reached $4.5 trillion, which led to it surpassing Japan and becoming the third-largest economy in the world.
The HCES 2022-23 results showed that the Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) in rural areas increased in real terms by 40 per cent over 2011-12. (page 220)
According to the state-wise destination of remittances in 2023-24, Maharashtra received the largest share at 20.5 per cent, followed by Kerala with a 19.7 per cent share. (Page 100, Table 2)
According to the new table under section 115BAC for the assessment year 2025-26, the tax rate for the income slab from Rs. 7,00,001 to Rs. 10,00,000 is 10 per cent. (Page 52)

Statement I is correct: Total Receipts were ₹12,82,709 crore, which is 36.7% of BE 2025-26. Statement II is incorrect: Total Expenditure was ₹18,80,862 crore, which is 37.1% of BE 2025-26 (the 30.9% figure was for the period upto July 2025). Statement III is correct: Capital Account Expenditure was ₹4,31,579 crore. Thus, I and III are correct.

The Government of India, in consultation with the RBI, finalized its borrowing programme for the second half of FY 2025-26 and planned to borrow ₹6.77 lakh crore through dated securities, including ₹10,000 crore via Sovereign Green Bonds.

Key provisions of the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, effective from August 1, 2025, include redefining the 'substantial interest' threshold from ₹5 lakh to ₹2 crore, increasing the maximum tenure of cooperative bank directors to 10 years, and permitting PSBs to transfer unclaimed shares, interest, and bond amounts to the Investor Education and Protection Fund (IEPF).
The fiscal deficit of the Union Government was brought down from 6.4 per cent of GDP in FY23 to 5.6 per cent of GDP in FY24, as per provisional actuals data. (page 64)
According to the performance metrics of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs), the Gross NPA ratio reached a multi-decadal low of 2.3 per cent as of March 2025. (Source: Page 55, Chart 1.44)

The amendment on September 4th, 2025, included mergers between a holding company and subsidiary companies but explicitly excluded cases where the transferor company is a listed company. Therefore, a merger where the transferor is a listed company is not permitted under the fast track procedure.
The amendment to section 194-O substitutes the words 'one per cent.' with '0.1 per cent.' for the TDS rate applicable to e-commerce operators, effective from October 1, 2024. (Page 73, 201)
As per the amendment to section 194H, the words 'five per cent.' have been substituted with 'two per cent.', reducing the TDS rate on commission or brokerage. (Page 72)

All three statements are correct. Banks are permitted to raise fresh FCNR(B) deposits of 1 year to less than 3 years maturity at rates not exceeding overnight Alternative Reference Rate (ARR) plus 400 bps (up from 250 bps). For deposits of 3 to 5 years maturity, the ceiling has been increased to overnight ARR plus 500 bps (up from 350 bps). This relaxation is available till March 31, 2025. (Page 12, 21)

Clause 3 of the Bill amends clause (42A) of section 2 to provide that a 'short-term capital asset' would mean a capital asset held for not more than twenty-four months immediately preceding the date of its transfer, down from thirty-six months. (Pages 33, 162)

Statement C is incorrect. According to the data provided, the annualized Return on Assets (RoA) for banks stood at 1.4 per cent, while the RoA for NBFCs stood at 3.2 per cent at end-June 2024. Therefore, the RoA for NBFCs was higher than that for banks. All other statements are correct based on the information in the footnote. (Page 12)
